message.content:
```json
{
  "filename": "awiqli-epar-product-information_en.pdf",
  "Document Type": "Summary of Product Characteristics (SmPC)",
  "Product Name": "Awiqli 700 units/mL solution for injection in pre-filled pen",
  "Active Substance(s)": "insulin icodec* (produced in Saccharomyces cerevisiae by recombinant DNA technology)",
  "Strength": "700 units/mL in 1 mL pen; 1050 units/mL in 1.5 mL pen; 2100 units/mL in 3 mL pen. Each mL contains 700 units (26.8 mg equivalent)",,
  "Pharmaceutical Form": "Solution for injection in pre-filled pen (FlexTouch), clear and colourless isotonic solution with pH of approximately 7.4",
  "Route of Administration": "Subcutaneous administration only",
  "Indications": "Treatment of diabetes mellitus in adults (both type 1 and type 2).",,Use with basal insulin for type 2 diabetes, or in combination with oral antidiabetic products, GLP-1 receptor agonists, and bolus insulin.",
  "Posology": "Basal insulin for once-weekly subcutaneous administration. Dosing depends on patient needs, typically starting at 70-140 units weekly depending on previous insulin regimen.

Specific dosing guidance:

*   **Initial Dosing (Type 2 Insulin-Naïve):** Based on current daily basal insulin dose multiplied by 7 (with adjustments).
    *   No adjustment needed after 2nd injection onwards (except for week 1).
*   **Missed Dose:** Inject as soon as possible unless it has been >3 days.
    *   Adjust subsequent weekly injection day if needed.
*   **Dosing:** Dial in specific units (10-700 units) using the pen's dose selector and counter.
*   **Injection Sites:** Rotate within the same region (thigh, upper arm, abdomen) to prevent lipodystrophy.

Maximum dose is 700 units per injection for 1mL pen or  1050/2100 units for larger pens.",
  "Contraindications": "Hypersensitivity to the active substance (insulin icodec or any excipient listed under section 6.1)",,
  "Special Warnings and Precautions": "Hypoglycaemia: Very common side effect, may be severe, need rapid assessment and glucose intake.

Hypersensitivity: Uncommon.

Injection site reactions: Common (erythema, pruritus).

Peripheral edema: Common.

Lipodystrophy/Amyloidosis: May occur if injection sites not rotated, may lead to delayed absorption.

Eye disorders: Possible transient worsening with improved glycaemic control.

Immunogenicity: Development of anti-insulin antibodies possible.

Switching Insulins: Potential errors, need careful patient instruction.

Mix-ups: Risk between insulins, confirm dose on pen label. Do not count clicks.

Mix-up: Confirm dose on pen label.

Other Medicines: Can interact (e.g. beta-blockers may mask hypoglycaemia symptoms).

Pregnancy: Lack of data, advised to discontinue if pregnancy occurs.

Breast-feeding: Potential risk to infant, advice to discontinute breast-feeding or the drug.

Driving and Machines: May affect ability due to hypoglycaemia or hyperglycaemia.",
  "Marketing Authorisation Holder": "Novo Nordisk A/S",
  "Marketing Authorisation Number": "EU/1/24/1815/001, EU/1/24/1815/002, EU/1/24/1815/003, EU/1/24/1815/004, EU/1/24/1815/005, EU/1/24/1815/006, EU/1/24/1815/007, EU/1/24/1815/008, EU/1/24/1815/009, EU/1/24/1815/010, EU/1/24/1815/011, EU/1/24/1815/012, EU/1/24/1815/013, EU/1/24/1815/014",
  "Date of First Authorisation": "May 17, 2024",
  "Date of Latest Renewal": "Not specified in the provided text.",
  "Shelf Life": "3 years.

After first opening: 12 weeks, store below 30°C, can be refrigerated, keep cap on.",
  "Storage Conditions": "See relevant sections:

Before First Use: Store in refrigerator (2°C - 8°C), do not freeze, keep away from freezing element, keep cap on for light protection.

After First Opening: Can be at room temperature (below 30°C) or in refrigerator (2°C - 8°C) for up to 12 weeks, store below 30°C, keep cap on.",
  "Package Description": "Solution for injection in pre-filled pen (FlexTouch) made of glass, halobutyl plunger/rubber sheet, contained in a multidose disposable pen made of polypropylene, polyoxymethylene, polycarbonate, acrylonitrile butadiene styrene. Contains specific amounts of glycerol, metacresol, phenol, zinc acetate, sodium chloride, hydrochloric acid, sodium hydroxide, and water for injections. Package includes cap (some pens), needles (various packs: 9, 14, or specific numbers in multipacks). Pack sizes vary (1 mL, 1.5 mL, 3 mL pens); needles are injection-only (NovoFine Plus). Excipients listed (Glycerol, metacresol, phenol, zinc acetate, sodium chloride, hydrochloric acid, sodium hydroxide, water for injections).",
  "Legal Category": "Prescription only (medical prescription required).",
  "ATC Code": "A10AE07",
  "Manufacturers": "Manufacturer of Active Substance: Novo Nordisk A/S, Hallas Alle 1, DK-4400 Kalundborg Denmark

Manufacturer responsible for batch release: Novo Nordisk A/S, Novo Alle 1, DK-2880 Bagsvaerd Denmark",
  "Excipients": "Glycerol, metacresol, phenol, zinc acetate, sodium chloride, hydrochloric acid, sodium hydroxide, water for injections"
}
```
message.reasoning:
Hmm, so I need to extract metadata from a pretty detailed document about the medicinal product Awiqli. This is definitely more complex than a standard extract because the text is structured as a summary of product characteristics for a drug called Awiqli, which contains insulin icodec. 

Okay, first I need to unpack what the user actually wants here. They provided both a detailed set of field specifications and a very thorough set of instructions about how to approach the extraction. The core task is to extract all information for each specified field from the given text. 

Looking at the text, I notice it's a massive document with multiple sections: introduction, composition, clinical particulars, pharmacological properties, pharmaceutical particulars, marketing info, etc. The level of detail is impressive - it even includes package leaflet content and storage instructions. 

First impression is this is going to require extremely careful scanning of the document. The user wants EVERYTHING, so I can't just pick the obvious fields. I need to systematically go through each section and pull out any relevant information for all fields, even if some might appear in unexpected places like headers or footers.

The format is very structured. Each section is clearly labeled, which is helpful. Starting with the document type and product name seems straightforward. The 'Summary of Product Characteristics' is explicitly stated in the document title. For the product name, it appears as both 'Awiqli' and 'insulin icodec' throughout the document.

Looking at the filename field, the document path is given at the very beginning as 'filename: awiqli-epar-product-information_en.pdf'. So that's clear.

For active substances, it's straightforward from the composition section. The astute observation here is that while the product is branded Awiqli, the active substance is still called insulin icodec.

The strength is given multiple times, but it's clear that it comes in different concentrations (700, 1050, 2100 units) and is packaged in various pen sizes (1mL, 1.5mL, 3mL). This means I need to document all variations.

Pharmaceutical form is clearly multiple formats - solution for injection in pre-filled pen, but also specifies the FlexTouch type when mentioned.

Route of administration is consistently reported across sections. Indications are clearly stated just applies to type 1 and type 2 diabetes.

Posology section is very detailed. This requires extracting not just the basic posology but also the specialized instructions for switching from other insulins, handling missed doses, etc.

The contraindications are clearly stated only relates to hypersensitivity. Special warnings and precautions span multiple sections - hypoglycaemia is a major risk mentioned repeatedly throughout the document.

Marketing info is comprehensive with Novo Nordisk as holder and several authorization numbers. Date of first authorization is explicitly '17 May 2024'.

Shelf life is '3 years' but also includes specific conditions after first opening. Storage instructions are detailed. Package description section has extensive details about the pen components and multipacks.

The legal category isn't explicitly stated but appears to be a prescription-only medication based on supply conditions.

ATC code is explicitly A10AE07 in the pharmacological properties section.

Manufacturers information is in both Annex II and the main text, both pointing to Novo Nordisk. Excipients are listed in several locations under different headings.

This appears to be an extremely thorough product information document. The instructions specifically mention that no field should be marked as "Not found" unless absolutely certain, which means even partial information should be included. The user likely needs this for regulatory or pharmaceutical database purposes.

My approach will be to work systematically through each field in order, carefully scanning all sections of the text for all referenced information. I'll be very methodical to ensure I cover everything, as missing even parts of the information could be critical in a metadata context.
